content:
Yes, there have been several notable Minor League Baseball players who have come from underserved communities and have later supported those communities, including:

1. Roberto Clemente: Clemente grew up in Puerto Rico and signed with the Brooklyn Dodgers in 1954. He played for their minor league team before being traded to the Pittsburgh Pirates, where he became a legend. Clemente was known for his charitable work and activism, especially in support of his native Puerto Rico and other Latin American countries. He died in a plane crash while delivering aid to earthquake victims in Nicaragua in 1972.

2. Curtis Granderson: Granderson grew up in Chicago and was drafted by the Detroit Tigers in 2002. He played for several teams in the major leagues before retiring in 2020. Granderson has been active in several philanthropic efforts, including his Grand Kids Foundation, which supports positive youth development in underserved communities.

3. CC Sabathia: Sabathia grew up in Vallejo, California, and was drafted by the Cleveland Indians in 1998. He played for several teams in the major leagues before retiring in 2019. Sabathia has been active in several charitable organizations, including the PitCCh In Foundation, which he started with his wife to support youth in underserved communities.

4. Ken Griffey Jr.: Griffey Jr. grew up in Cincinnati, Ohio, and was drafted by the Seattle Mariners in 1987. He played for several teams in the major leagues before retiring in 2010. Griffey Jr. has been active in several philanthropic efforts, including the Boys and Girls Clubs of America, which he has supported for over 20 years.

These are just a few examples of Minor League Baseball players who have come from underserved communities and have later supported those communities through their charitable work and activism.
